column1: Cape Coral is a large peninsula and is bordered in the south and east by the Caloosahatchee River and in the west by Matlacha Pass.  The city of Fort Myers lies across the Caloosahatchee River to the east
column2: and Matlacha and Pine Island lie across Matlacha Pass to the west. Matlacha Pass is home to Matlacha Pass National Wildlife Refuge and the state's Matlacha Pass Aquatic Preserve.

column1: The city has over 400 miles (640 km) of canals. Most of the canals are navigable and some have access to the Gulf of Mexico. Cape Coral's canal system is so extensive that local ecology and tides have been affected.
The city features a borderline tropical savanna climate (Köppen climate classification: Aw)
column2: bordering on a tropical monsoon climate (Köppen climate classification: Am)The area averages 355 days of sunshine each year
column3: but experiences precipitation on 145 days per year. While the summers are very warm
column5: and rainy
column6: the winters in Cape Coral are dry with moderate temperatures. The city receives about 56 inches of rain each year
column7: the majority of which falls from June to September. During the summer months
column8: afternoon rains are heavy yet brief. The city is affected by the annual hurricane season
column9: which begins officially on June 1 and continues through November.

column2: Cape Coral is the eighth largest city in Florida by population. More than 60 percent of the population is between the ages of 15–64 and residents under 25 outnumber residents over 65. Southwest Florida's 18–24 age group is growing at a faster rate than the state of Florida and the United States.

column1: The City of Cape Coral operates under the council-manager government form of government. City Council members are elected at large from seven districts. The mayor is also elected at large and is the eighth member of the council. The mayor presides over council meetings. The City of Cape Coral provides police and fire services within the city.

Interstate 75 passes within 10 miles (16 km) of Cape Coral and connects northward to Tampa; and southeastward to Miami/Fort Lauderdale. Cape Coral borders on U.S. Highway 41. U.S. 41 and I-75 can be accessed from State Route 78 (Pine Island Road). Within the city a network of arterial roadways are established. Cape Coral has approximately 1
column4: the north/south routes are evenly spaced apart every one or two miles (3 km) and most of them have at least four lanes.

column1: Cape Coral is connected to Fort Myers by two bridges. The 3
column3: 000 m) long Cape Coral Bridge connects Cape Coral Parkway to College Parkway in Fort Myers. The Midpoint Memorial Bridge connects Veterans Parkway to Colonial Boulevard. A number of other bridges span the Caloosahatchee River just east of Cape Coral in adjoining North Fort Myers.

column1: Public transit services in Cape Coral are provided by LeeTran. LeeTran operates 18 fixed-route bus services
Cape Coral is 14 miles (23 km) from Southwest Florida International Airport (RSW)
column2: which serves nearly ten million passengers annually. The airport's new Midfield Terminal Complex opened in 2005
column3: with three concourses and 28 gates. In 2010
column4: eighteen national and two international airlines
column5: as well as the two major cargo companies
column6: served the airport.

column1: In addition to Southwest Florida International Airport
column2: Cape Coral is also served by Page Field
column3: a general aviation airport in Fort Myers eight miles (13 km) from Cape Coral. Charlotte County Airport (PGD) is located in Punta Gorda
column4: just 10 miles (16 km) north of Cape Coral.

column1: The Cape was among the first in Florida to deploy the new 4.9 GHz pre-WiMax wireless channel authorized by the FCC in 2003 for exclusive Public Safety use.
The economy in Cape Coral is based on health care services
column3: and real estate/construction.  The City's Economic Development Office promotes and incentivizes business relocation to Cape Coral.  In 2016 the city's top five employers were the Lee Memorial Hospital
column5: Publix Supermarkets
column6: City of Cape Coral and Walmart.

column1: The area is known by birding enthusiasts for a wide variety of wildlife and the largest population of burrowing owls in the state of Florida.
Several parks and ecological preserves allow observation of the local wildlife.  Elevated nature trails wind through the mangroves at Four Mile Cove Ecological Preserve.

Cape Coral's 400-mile (640 km) canal system provides many residents with waterfront living with access to the Gulf of Mexico via the broad Caloosahatchee River and Matlacha Pass. The Parks and Recreation Department maintains three public boat launching facilities.  The Gulf of Mexico provides access to smaller tropical islands

column1: The Southwest Florida Military Museum located in downtown Cape Coral
column2: features a wide collection of military artifacts from all points of the United States 244 year history.

column1: Nature enthusiasts can track exotic birds and native fish from the boardwalk at Lake Kennedy and watch the West Indian manatees at Sirenia Vista Park. Cape Coral is home to the largest population of burrowing owls in Florida.
